overview.short: Enterobacter asburiae is a Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic rod within the Enterobacter cloacae complex, less commonly isolated than E. cloacae or E. hormaechei.
overview.clinical_context: Typically associated with opportunistic infections, including urinary tract, wound, and bloodstream infections, primarily in immunocompromised or hospitalised patients.

species_markers.notes: Helps distinguish E. asburiae from lysine-positive Enterobacter species.
Key discriminator separating E. asburiae from E. hormaechei.
Differentiates E. asburiae from rhamnose-positive E. hormaechei.
More consistently positive in E. asburiae than in some other complex members.

common_confusions.reason: Shared general biochemical profile and overlapping sugar fermentation patterns.
Overlapping colony morphology and growth characteristics within the E. cloacae complex.

when_to_question_identification: Ornithine decarboxylase positivity argues against E. asburiae.
Rhamnose positivity suggests E. hormaechei rather than E. asburiae.
Lysine decarboxylase positivity is inconsistent with E. asburiae.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Helpful in separating E. asburiae from other Enterobacter species.
Supports differentiation within the E. cloacae complex.
Preferred routine method for accurate species-level identification.
Definitive resolution when species-level precision is clinically critical.
